comment_text.mn46:1.1: The Buddha delves into this topic in more detail in MN 114.
comment_text.mn46:20.1: Rancid urine was the worst of medicines, used when nothing better was available. Specifically, the Vinaya allows it as a purgative in the case of snakebite (Kd 6:14.6.4), and gives chebulic myrobalan soaked in cattle urine as a remedy for jaundice (Kd 6:14.7.9). Modern research has shown that urine, far from being a sterile cure-all, contains dangerous levels of bacterial pathogens, and has no medicinal value.
comment_text.mn46:22.2: This text as well as MN 45:7.9 answer the question of what practice results in future happiness, and so do not consider awakening. It is surprising to see such bold praise for such a modest teaching. The Chinese parallels to these suttas have the inverse situation, as they describe a practice leading to non-return (MA 174 at T i 712b27) or Nibbana (MA 175 at T i 712c25, T 83 at T i 902c10), yet do not have this passage of praise.

root_text.mn46:2.2: ‘aho vata aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā parihāyeyyuṁ, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍheyyun’ti.
root_text.mn46:2.3: Tesaṁ, bhikkhave, sattānaṁ evaṅkāmānaṁ evaṁchandānaṁ evaṁadhippāyānaṁ aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā parihāyanti.
root_text.mn46:2.4: Tatra tumhe, bhikkhave, kaṁ hetuṁ paccethā”ti?
root_text.mn46:2.5: “Bhagavaṁmūlakā no, bhante, dhammā, bhagavaṁnettikā, bhagavaṁpaṭisaraṇā. Sādhu vata, bhante, bhagavantaññeva paṭibhātu etassa bhāsitassa attho; bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
root_text.mn46:2.6: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, suṇātha, sādhukaṁ manasi karotha, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.mn46:2.7: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
root_text.mn46:3.1: “Idha, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano, ariyānaṁ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṁ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto,
root_text.mn46:3.2: sevitabbe dhamme na jānāti asevitabbe dhamme na jānāti, bhajitabbe dhamme na jānāti abhajitabbe dhamme na jānāti.
root_text.mn46:3.3: So sevitabbe dhamme ajānanto asevitabbe dhamme ajānanto, bhajitabbe dhamme ajānanto abhajitabbe dhamme ajānanto, asevitabbe dhamme sevati sevitabbe dhamme na sevati, abhajitabbe dhamme bhajati bhajitabbe dhamme na bhajati.
root_text.mn46:3.4: Tassa asevitabbe dhamme sevato sevitabbe dhamme asevato, abhajitabbe dhamme bhajato bhajitabbe dhamme abhajato aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā parihāyanti.
root_text.mn46:3.6: Evañhetaṁ, bhikkhave, hoti yathā taṁ aviddasuno.
root_text.mn46:4.1: Sutavā ca kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako, ariyānaṁ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto, sappurisānaṁ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto,
root_text.mn46:4.2: sevitabbe dhamme jānāti asevitabbe dhamme jānāti, bhajitabbe dhamme jānāti abhajitabbe dhamme jānāti.
root_text.mn46:4.3: So sevitabbe dhamme jānanto asevitabbe dhamme jānanto, bhajitabbe dhamme jānanto abhajitabbe dhamme jānanto, asevitabbe dhamme na sevati sevitabbe dhamme sevati, abhajitabbe dhamme na bhajati bhajitabbe dhamme bhajati.
root_text.mn46:4.4: Tassa asevitabbe dhamme asevato sevitabbe dhamme sevato, abhajitabbe dhamme abhajato bhajitabbe dhamme bhajato, aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā dhammā parihāyanti, iṭṭhā kantā manāpā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti.

root_text.mn46:14.1: Katamañca, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ?
root_text.mn46:14.2: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pāṇātipātī hoti, pāṇātipātapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.3: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena adinnādāyī hoti, adinnādānapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.4: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena kāmesu micchācārī hoti, kāmesu micchācārapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.5: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena musāvādī hoti, musāvādapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.6: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pisuṇavāco hoti, pisuṇavācāpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.7: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena pharusavāco hoti, pharusavācāpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.8: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena samphappalāpī hoti, samphappalāpapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.9: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena abhijjhālu hoti, abhijjhāpaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.10: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena byāpannacitto hoti, byāpādapaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti;
root_text.mn46:14.11: sahāpi dukkhena sahāpi domanassena micchādiṭṭhi hoti, micchādiṭṭhipaccayā ca dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
root_text.mn46:14.12: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn46:14.13: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhañceva āyatiñca dukkhavipākaṁ.

root_text.mn46:19.3: Atha puriso āgaccheyya jīvitukāmo amaritukāmo sukhakāmo dukkhappaṭikūlo.
root_text.mn46:19.5: ‘ambho purisa, ayaṁ āpānīyakaṁso vaṇṇasampanno gandhasampanno rasasampanno.
root_text.mn46:19.8: Tassa te pivatohi kho chādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṁ vā nigacchasi maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhan’ti.
root_text.mn46:19.10: Tassa taṁ pivatohi kho chādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana maraṇaṁ vā nigaccheyya maraṇamattaṁ vā dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn46:19.11: Tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ vadāmi, yamidaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhaṁ āyatiṁ dukkhavipākaṁ.
root_text.mn46:20.4: ‘ambho purisa, idaṁ pūtimuttaṁ nānābhesajjehi saṁsaṭṭhaṁ, sace ākaṅkhasi piva.
root_text.mn46:20.5: Tassa te pivatohi kho nacchādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana sukhī bhavissasī’ti.
root_text.mn46:20.7: Tassa taṁ pivatohi kho nacchādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana sukhī assa.
root_text.mn46:20.8: Tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ vadāmi, yamidaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannadukkhaṁ āyatiṁ sukhavipākaṁ.
root_text.mn46:21.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dadhi ca madhu ca sappi ca phāṇitañca ekajjhaṁ saṁsaṭṭhaṁ.
root_text.mn46:21.4: ‘ambho purisa, idaṁ dadhi ca madhu ca sappi ca phāṇitañca ekajjhaṁ saṁsaṭṭhaṁ, sace ākaṅkhasi piva.
root_text.mn46:21.5: Tassa te pivato ceva chādessati vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana sukhī bhavissasī’ti.
root_text.mn46:21.7: Tassa taṁ pivato ceva chādeyya vaṇṇenapi gandhenapi rasenapi, pivitvā ca pana sukhī assa.
root_text.mn46:21.8: Tathūpamāhaṁ, bhikkhave, imaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ vadāmi, yamidaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṁ.
root_text.mn46:22.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, vassānaṁ pacchime māse saradasamaye viddhe vigatavalāhake deve ādicco nabhaṁ abbhussakkamāno sabbaṁ ākāsagataṁ tamagataṁ abhivihacca bhāsate ca tapate ca virocate ca;
root_text.mn46:22.2: evameva kho, bhikkhave, yamidaṁ dhammasamādānaṁ paccuppannasukhañceva āyatiñca sukhavipākaṁ tadaññe puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇaparappavāde abhivihacca bhāsate ca tapate ca virocate cā”ti.
root_text.mn46:22.4: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn46:0.2: The Great Discourse on Taking Up Practices
translation_text.mn46:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn46:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn46:2.1: “Mendicants, sentient beings typically have the wish, desire, and hope:
translation_text.mn46:2.2: ‘Oh, if only unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things would decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things would increase!’
translation_text.mn46:2.3: But exactly the opposite happens to them.
translation_text.mn46:2.4: What do you take to be the reason for this?”
translation_text.mn46:2.5: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
translation_text.mn46:2.6: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn46:3.1: “Take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
translation_text.mn46:3.2: They don’t know what practices they should cultivate and foster, and what practices they shouldn’t cultivate and foster.
translation_text.mn46:3.3: So they cultivate and foster practices they shouldn’t, and don’t cultivate and foster practices they should.
translation_text.mn46:3.4: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things increase, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things decrease.
translation_text.mn46:3.6: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who doesn’t know.
translation_text.mn46:4.1: But a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.
translation_text.mn46:4.2: They know what practices they should cultivate and foster, and what practices they shouldn’t cultivate and foster.
translation_text.mn46:4.3: So they cultivate and foster practices they should, and don’t cultivate and foster practices they shouldn’t.
translation_text.mn46:4.4: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase.
translation_text.mn46:4.6: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who knows.
translation_text.mn46:5.1: Mendicants, there are these four ways of taking up practices.
translation_text.mn46:5.3: There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.
translation_text.mn46:5.4: There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.
translation_text.mn46:5.5: There is a way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.
translation_text.mn46:5.6: There is a way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.
translation_text.mn46:6.1: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, an ignoramus, without knowing this, doesn’t truly understand:
translation_text.mn46:6.2: ‘This is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.’
translation_text.mn46:6.3: So instead of avoiding that practice, they cultivate it.
translation_text.mn46:6.4: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things increase, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things decrease.
translation_text.mn46:6.6: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who doesn’t know.
translation_text.mn46:7.1: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, an ignoramus …
translation_text.mn46:8.1: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pleasure, an ignoramus …
translation_text.mn46:9.1: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure, an ignoramus …
translation_text.mn46:9.6: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who doesn’t know.
translation_text.mn46:10.1: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, a wise person, knowing this, truly understands:
translation_text.mn46:10.2: ‘This is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.’
translation_text.mn46:10.3: So instead of cultivating that practice, they avoid it.
translation_text.mn46:10.4: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase.
translation_text.mn46:10.6: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who knows.
translation_text.mn46:11.1: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, a wise person …
translation_text.mn46:12.1: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pleasure, a wise person …
translation_text.mn46:13.1: When it comes to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure, a wise person, knowing this, truly understands:
translation_text.mn46:13.2: ‘This is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.’
translation_text.mn46:13.3: So instead of avoiding that practice, they cultivate it.
translation_text.mn46:13.4: When they do so, unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable things decrease, and likable, desirable, and agreeable things increase.
translation_text.mn46:13.6: Because that’s what it’s like for someone who knows.
translation_text.mn46:14.1: And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain?
translation_text.mn46:14.2: It’s when someone in pain and sadness kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view. Because of these things they experience pain and sadness.
translation_text.mn46:14.12: And when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn46:14.13: This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain.
translation_text.mn46:15.1: And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain?
translation_text.mn46:15.2: It’s when someone with pleasure and happiness kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct. They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re covetous, malicious, with wrong view. Because of these things they experience pleasure and happiness.
translation_text.mn46:15.12: But when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn46:15.13: This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now but results in future pain.
translation_text.mn46:16.1: And what is the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure?
translation_text.mn46:16.2: It’s when someone in pain and sadness doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. Because of these things they experience pain and sadness.
translation_text.mn46:16.12: But when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn46:16.13: This is called the way of taking up practices that is painful now but results in future pleasure.
translation_text.mn46:17.1: And what is the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure?
translation_text.mn46:17.2: It’s when someone with pleasure and happiness doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. Because of these things they experience pleasure and happiness.
translation_text.mn46:17.12: And when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
translation_text.mn46:17.13: This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.
translation_text.mn46:17.14: These are the four ways of taking up practices.
translation_text.mn46:18.1: Suppose there was some bitter gourd mixed with poison.
translation_text.mn46:18.2: Then a man would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
translation_text.mn46:18.4: ‘Here, worthy man, this is bitter gourd mixed with poison.
translation_text.mn46:18.6: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be unappetizing, and it will result in death or deadly pain.’
translation_text.mn46:18.7: He wouldn’t put it down. Without reflection, he’d drink it.
translation_text.mn46:18.8: The color, aroma, and flavor would be unappetizing, and it would result in death or deadly pain.
translation_text.mn46:18.9: This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pain, I say.
translation_text.mn46:19.1: Suppose there was a bronze goblet of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor.
translation_text.mn46:19.2: But it was mixed with poison.
translation_text.mn46:19.3: Then a man would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
translation_text.mn46:19.5: ‘Here, worthy man, this bronze goblet of beverage has a nice color, aroma, and flavor.
translation_text.mn46:19.8: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be appetizing, but it will result in death or deadly pain.’
translation_text.mn46:19.9: He wouldn’t put it down. Without reflection, he’d drink it.
translation_text.mn46:19.10: The color, aroma, and flavor would be appetizing, but it would result in death or deadly pain.
translation_text.mn46:19.11: This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pain, I say.
translation_text.mn46:20.1: Suppose there was some rancid urine mixed with different medicines.
translation_text.mn46:20.2: Then a man with jaundice would come along.
translation_text.mn46:20.4: ‘Here, worthy man, this is rancid urine mixed with different medicines. Drink it if you like.
translation_text.mn46:20.5: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be unappetizing, but after drinking it you will be happy.’
translation_text.mn46:20.6: He wouldn’t put it down. After appraisal, he’d drink it.
translation_text.mn46:20.7: The color, aroma, and flavor would be unappetizing, but after drinking it he would be happy.
translation_text.mn46:20.8: This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is painful now and results in future pleasure, I say.
translation_text.mn46:21.1: Suppose there was some curds, honey, ghee, and molasses all mixed together.
translation_text.mn46:21.2: Then a man with bloody dysentery would come along.
translation_text.mn46:21.4: ‘Here, worthy man, this is curds, honey, ghee, and molasses all mixed together. Drink it if you like.
translation_text.mn46:21.5: If you drink it, the color, aroma, and flavor will be appetizing, and after drinking it you will be happy.’
translation_text.mn46:21.6: He wouldn’t put it down. After appraisal, he’d drink it.
translation_text.mn46:21.7: The color, aroma, and flavor would be appetizing, and after drinking it he would be happy.
translation_text.mn46:21.8: This is comparable to the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure, I say.
translation_text.mn46:22.1: It’s like the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, when the heavens are sunny and cloudless. And as the sun is rising to the firmament, having dispelled all the darkness of space, it shines and glows and radiates.
translation_text.mn46:22.2: In the same way, this way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure dispels the doctrines of the various other ascetics and brahmins as it shines and glows and radiates.”
translation_text.mn46:22.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn46:22.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

variant_text.mn46:18.6: pivitvā → pītvā (bj, pts1ed) | pivato → pipato (si, pts1ed)
